nodes.text: Changing how students are allocated to colleges can substantially reduce parental-income segregation across colleges and increase intergenerational income mobility among college students

Method: Constructed near-complete linked administrative data (federal tax records, Department of Education 1098-T and Pell records, College Board and ACT) for U.S. college students (1999–2013) to obtain parents' household incomes, students' colleges, SAT/ACT scores, and students' earnings in early 30s
Result: The degree of parental income segregation across colleges is very high and comparable to income segregation across childhood neighborhoods (ZIP codes)

Evidence: At Ivy-Plus colleges, 14.5% of students come from top 1% families and only 3.8% from bottom quintile; children from top 1% are about 77 times more likely to attend Ivy-Plus than children from bottom quintile

Result/Evidence: Differences in students' earnings between children from low- and high-income families are much smaller within the same college than across colleges; national parent-child rank slope ~0.29, controlling for college fixed effects falls to ~0.10

Evidence (robustness): The within-college flattening of the parent-child earnings relationship holds controlling for SAT/ACT bins, high-school fixed effects, gender, and when restricting to college-goers; sensitivity checks show results are not driven by labor-force participation or cost-of-living adjustments

Claim/Evidence: Some colleges, notably several mid-tier public institutions (e.g., CUNY campuses, certain California State and University of Texas campuses), combine high shares of low-income students with relatively strong earnings outcomes for those students, yielding high bottom-to-top-quintile mobility rates

Method/Claim: Simulated counterfactual student reallocations using linked data and SAT/ACT scores: (i) income-neutral allocation (randomize enrollment conditional on test score, race, state, keep college sizes and racial/geographic composition fixed); (ii) need-affirmative allocation (apply a sliding-scale test-score boost to lower-income students); compute impacts on segregation and mobility assuming a causal share parameter

Result (simulation): Income-neutral allocation conditional on test scores would substantially reduce segregation (e.g., selective colleges' underrepresentation of bottom-quintile students falls by 38%) and reduce the gap in top-quintile attainment between children from top vs bottom parents by about 15% assuming 80% of conditional earnings differences are causal

Result (simulation): Need-affirmative allocation (example: 160-SAT-point boost for bottom-quintile, decreasing linearly by quintile) would essentially eliminate parental-income differences across college tiers and could reduce intergenerational income persistence among college students by about 25% under the baseline 80% causal assumption

Evidence: SAT/ACT by parental income: high-scoring students are disproportionately from high-income families; there are very few high-scoring low-income students (e.g., about 3.7% of college students scoring 1300+ are from bottom quintile), limiting the ability of purely score-conditional policies to expand low-income representation at the very top colleges

Assumption/Evidence: Baseline simulations assume 80% of conditional differences in student earnings across colleges (conditional on parental income, race, and test scores) reflect causal college value-added; this assumption is supported by regressions that control for observable covariates and students' application sets yielding λ ≈ 0.8–1.0

Limitation: Results are sensitive to the assumed causal share and neglect potential changes in colleges' value-added, peer effects, or equilibrium labor market responses under large reallocations; simulated magnitudes should be interpreted with caution

Conclusion: Feasible changes in how students are allocated to colleges—through policies affecting application, admission, or matriculation—could substantially reduce income segregation and meaningfully increase intergenerational mobility even without changing colleges' educational programs, though precise effects depend on causal assumptions

Evidence: Exposure index comparison shows college peers' parental-income composition is on average as segregated as childhood ZIP-code peers (e.g., among bottom-quintile children, fraction of peers from top quintile is 13.7% in childhood vs 22.5% in college when excluding non-college-goers; overall college and neighborhood segregation are similar)

Evidence/Claim: Heterogeneity in mobility patterns: Ivy-Plus and other elite private colleges concentrate upper-tail mobility (bottom to top 1%) while some mid-tier public colleges generate high bottom-to-top-20% mobility; institution types associated with upper-tail mobility differ systematically (selective, high-endowment) from those associated with broader upward mobility
